channel.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
channel.description:
[img]http://realitypod.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/iPhone-5-Concept.jpg[/img]
In addition to Foxconn - Apple’s longtime partner and manufacturer of the iPhone - another Taiwanese company is said to have struck a deal with Cupertino to build as many as 15 million iPhones.
Citing the usual upstream component makers, industry publication DigiTimes reports that Taiwan-based notebook maker Pegatron Technology is estimated to have been contracted by Apple to build 15 million units of the next-generation iPhone.
These sources appear to be unsure whether Pegatron will be assembling an iPhone 5, or an iPhone 4S, which makes the report a tad less credible.
The sources, nonetheless, said the iPhone 5 does not “seem” to be very different from the current model (the iPhone 4), but that the smartphone is already set for shipment in September.
Pegatron wants to also build iPads and MacBooks, but Apple has already landed orders with many of the manufacturer’s competitors, and therefore has been left out in the cold, the report adds.
Only under the consideration of separating risks may Pegatron have a chance to land a small volume of iPad orders in 2012, market watchers believe.
It is also being reported that Pegatron has significantly expanded its plants, human resources and equipment in 2010. in order to satisfy orders for some 10 million CDMA iPhone 4 units, as a result of its cooperation with Apple.
However, the CDMA version of Apple’s popular gadget sold far less than expected in the first quarter of 2011, which saw Pegatron ship less than four million units.
This caused the company's utilization rate to drop to 50% with its gross margin weakening to 1.8% in the quarter, reports DigiTimes.
Apple is expected to unveil its next-generation iPhone at a fall event. The Cupertino tech giant has already confirmed plans to launch iOS 5 and iCloud this autumn, both of which will leverage new hardware.
[size=13pt]This post was found on another forum website (psperspective.net) in under the TECH NEWS thread. I have copied that post here for users of Moparisthebest to view. I have NOT written this post myself. This is just to inform Moparisthebest users... [/size]

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I like having my sat nav, phone, mp3 player, games console, camera, video player, internet browser amongst other things on one device, saves me carrying around multiple. I think smartphones these days are doing pretty well for themselves… I only have the ZTE Blade and its a fairly low spec phone however it does everything I need and costs under £100, plus the battery life lasts 2 days at a push, which I think is pretty good.

Read full topic
item.source: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:402804”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=499863.msg3663804#msg3663804 date=1310502803]

Because you guys don’t sleep at night so you can plug them in? Since you would presumably have to be a vampire or something to stay awake for 7 days. 1.5 days or so is all the battery life you really need, not to mention if you have a decent phone you could just carry around an extra battery to swap out.
[/quote]I go to festivals every year, on those places you can’t charge phones because there’s no electricity at camping sites.

Fair enough, so take a ‘dumb’ phone just to those things, or carry some extra batteries?[/quote]But i wouldnt even want a smartphone in the first place. To me it’s just a huge waste of money!

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

It is a point. I’m alright with it, because I’ll constantly have stuff being updated to my phone (plenty of new podcasts, etc) - so I’ll have mine on charge once I get home.

But there doesn’t seem to be much progress in regards to battery life in smartphones.

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

mutex_:

I’m confused about the manufacturing aspect. When a company is contracted by Apple to make their product, it’s not like the contracted company has the machinery to build the phone, do they? Does Apple provide a blueprint and then the company has to manufacture based on that blueprint?

nah from what i understand its like a standard machine that assembles the phones they just calibrate it differently or modify it slightly for apple’s specs

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @tL tL

@tL wrote:

It won’t go 4G for a good long while. Apple don’t like to segment, and they’ll likely wait till it is a standard. Which it isn’t yet.

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

its still not 4G,hasnt got NFC, only 512 RAM, the front facing camera is wank there may be other hardware aspects it needs to improve on aside from mine and the ones you mentioned but i cant think of them right now, also even if it updated all of the things we’ve just mentioned it’d be a massive update

Read full topic
item.source: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

It isn’t even that. Aside from dual core processors and perhaps a better camera, there isn’t really much they can do. With the 3GS they were well behind in regards to hardware, the iPhone 4 is still up there with the best, with only one or two phones pulling ahead (Galaxy S II and Motorola Atrix).

Read full topic
item.source: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers

item.title: iPhone 5 Not Very Different from iPhone 4, Say Component Makers
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

its obviously not gonna be much different its apples tic toc update scheme, 3G -> 3GS was hardly a difference, 3GS -> 4, substantial difference. One update will be a marginal improvement one will be an actual update, apple do this all the time

Read full topic
